attempts.summary: All rubric items are met: the slide clearly reads as a cover/title slide with minimal text, the giant chat bubble with dots and hourglass conveys waiting, the title 'LLM Latency' is visible and legible in the top-left, and the overall style is playful and cute with a pastel palette.
All rubric conditions are fully satisfied; the slide passes.

All rubric items are met: the slide clearly works as a section opener, the title 'What slows' is visible in the top-left, the composition is playful and minimal with a large central illustration, and it uses a pastel palette with rounded, soft shapes. Only minor tweaks to emphasis and visual hierarchy could further strengthen it.

failures: Extra text beyond the specified labels appears: 'REQUESTS' and 'SLOW PROCESS' on the signpost, and an exclamation-mark icon on the warning triangle instead of being text-free.
The warning triangle is not small relative to the rest of the diagram; it is fairly prominent under the machine.
Prompt requested 'Only text: "What makes it slow?"', but additional words are present on the slide.
attempts.summary: The visual style and section-opener feel are strong, but the slide fails the strict text constraint by including extra labels and symbols beyond the required title, and the warning triangle is not particularly small.

failures: The warning triangle contains an exclamation mark, which violates the requirement that the signpost and any icons be purely graphical with no letters or symbols.
attempts.summary: The slide otherwise meets the style, title text, no-extra-text, and section-opener requirements, but it fails the strict icon specification because the warning triangle includes an exclamation mark symbol.

failures: Extra text appears on the slide beyond the specified labels: the signpost contains the words 'Request' and 'Processing', which are not allowed by the prompt specifying only the text 'What makes it slow?'.

While the overall illustration is clean and technical, the presence of labeled signpost text slightly breaks the strict 'only specified text' requirement, weakening the deadpan corporate-technical minimalism requested.
attempts.summary: The visual style and section-opener feel work, and the title is correct, but the slide fails due to extra text ('Request', 'Processing') that violates the requirement that only 'What makes it slow?' appear as text.

All rubric items are satisfied: the slide uses a clean, deadpan technical diagram style; the only text is the correctly placed title 'What makes it slow?'; the diagram elements are purely graphical with no labels; and the composition clearly reads as a section opener.

Pass. TTFT and TBT labels are clearly visible and legible under their respective icons, a p95 indicator appears as a small curve/graph with the label ‘p95’, the title ‘Metrics’ is visible at the top-left, and the overall style is playful, minimal, and uses simple, cute vector icons matching the prompt.

All rubric items are satisfied: the pipeline includes network, queue, prefill, decode, and service segments in a single horizontal bar; labels are short and legible; the title 'Budget' is visible near the top-left; and the overall style is playful, clean, and infographic-like.

All rubric items are satisfied: the triangle clearly shows the three corners labeled ‘capability’, ‘cost’, and ‘latency’; labels are short and legible; the title ‘Tradeoffs’ is visible in the top-left; and the overall style is playful, cute, and relatively minimal with a strong central illustration. Only minor refinements to emphasis and clutter could improve clarity further.

All rubric items are met. TTFT and TBT are clearly distinct, with TTFT as a single block and TBT as repeating ticks/labels along a left-to-right timeline. The title 'Phases' is visible in the top-left, and the overall design is playful, cute, minimal, and consistent with the requested pastel vector style.

All rubric items are met: the output token chain is clearly longer than the small input block, the clocks and varied hand positions visually imply each token adds time, the title ‘Output’ is visible in the top-left, and the overall style is playful, rounded, pastel, and friendly. Only minor clarity tweaks are suggested.

All rubric items are satisfied: there is a scatter plot with labeled axes ('ms/token' and 'tok/min/GPU'), the axis labels are short and readable, the dots form a clear upward trend, and the title 'Cadence' appears prominently at the top-left.

All rubric items are met: the three model blocks clearly increase in size and are labeled small/medium/large; the speed gauge points to higher speed near the smallest block area, visually implying larger size is slower; the title 'Size' is clearly visible in the top-left; and the overall design is playful, minimal, and matches the requested pastel, rounded vector style.

failures: Title 'Input vs output' is not in the top-left corner as requested; it is centered near the top instead.
attempts.summary: Most rubric items are met: input and output lanes are clearly labeled, the output appears more valuable (larger pills, sparkles, coins) and implies more processing time, and the style is playful with a clear composition. The only miss is that the title is not placed in the top-left as specified, so adjust its position to fully match the rubric.

All rubric items are met: both lanes are clearly labeled Input and Output, the output lane conveys higher value with larger, more elaborate pills and a heart, the title 'Input vs output' is visible at the top, and the style is playful, pastel, and cleanly composed. Minor tweaks could further stress the slower/more expensive nature of the output.

All rubric items are met: context growth is visualized by a lengthening KV trailer, KV/memory growth is implied by increasing disk stacks with arrows, the title 'Context' is clearly visible in the top-left, and the illustration is playful, cute, and minimal in style using a pastel palette. Minor tweaks could make the growth and memory-pressure concepts even more explicit.

All rubric items are met: the cached segment is clearly highlighted with bright color and a check icon, the uncached new segment is visible and gray for contrast, the title 'Cached prefix' is clearly readable in the top-left, and the overall style is playful, clean, and vector-based.

All rubric items are satisfied: the left side shows wide vehicles squeezed into a narrow lane (batching difficulty), the right side shows a clear rising cost curve labeled 'cost', the title 'Long requests' is visible in the top-left, and the illustration uses a playful, minimal vector style with pastel colors and soft shapes.

All rubric items are satisfied: a clear queue of cars is visible at the toll booth, delay is indicated by a large clock and a “DELAY” sign, the title “Congestion” appears at the top left, and the overall style is playful, vector-like, minimal, and uses a soft pastel palette on an off‑white background.

All rubric items are met: the ramp light pulses are clearly visible around the green and red lights, low vs high batch behavior is implied by a few cars flowing versus a long queue then large release, the title 'Batching' is visible in the top-left, and the overall style is playful, cute, and minimal with pastel colors and soft shadows.

All rubric items are satisfied: two distinct routing choices are clearly visible, the wait vs travel tradeoff is implied with a queued path vs a timed world-route, the title 'Routing' appears in the top-left, and the overall style is playful, cute, and minimal with pastel colors and rounded shapes.

All rubric items are met: smaller models are represented by stacks of blocks with fewer pieces, speed improvement is implied by the gauge and faster rabbit versus slower turtle, the title 'Smaller' is clearly visible in the top-left, and the overall style is playful and cute with pastel colors and rounded vector shapes.

All rubric items are satisfied: the router clearly routes tokens to a subset of brighter, active expert blocks while others are visibly dimmed; the title ‘MoE’ is present in the top-left; and the overall style is playful, cute, and clean with a clear central composition.

All rubric items are clearly met: the playful pastel vector style is correct, the title ‘Proxy’ is visible in the top-left, a stream of draft tokens flows into a central checkmark gate (verification step), and the output side suggests a grouped/batch result. Only minor tweaks are needed to more overtly signal ‘batch’ and enhance slide readability.

All rubric items are met: the 16-bit → 8-bit → 4-bit ladder clearly shows lower precision steps, the large rising arrow behind the chip implies speed increase, the word 'Quantize' is visible at the top-left, and the overall illustration is playful, cute, and pastel. Only minor clarifications could make the message even more explicit.

All rubric items are met: cache reuse is clearly depicted with arrows between colorful memory blocks, eviction is visually de-emphasized using a dim gray sad block, the title 'KV cache' is clearly visible in the top-left, and the style is playful, minimal, and pastel. Only minor tweaks are possible to further highlight reuse and downplay eviction.

All rubric items are met: additional capacity is depicted with a second rack cluster and a plus sign, the queue on the right is shorter than the queue on the left, the title ‘Capacity’ is clearly visible in the top-left, and the illustration uses a playful, cute vector style with pastel colors and rounded shapes.

All rubric items are met: a single giant wafer-scale chip is central, speed improvement is implied by the fast arrow and flowing tokens, the title 'Wafer' is clearly visible, and the style is playful, cute, and minimal.

All rubric items are satisfied: the slide has a clean corporate technical diagram style, the title text is exactly 'TTFT vs TBT', only the specified text labels appear, the full token strip with prompt and output segments is visible, the left segment is labeled 'TTFT', and the right segment is labeled 'TBT' with 'x N' under the output segment. The design passes with only minor optional refinements suggested.
All rubric items satisfied: correct title text, only specified labels, all required pipeline segments present and legible, and the visual style matches a clean, deadpan corporate technical diagram.

failures: The slide contains extra text beyond the specified labels: 'Input', 'Compute', and multiple 'Output' labels appear even though the prompt says the only text should be 'Why output dominates'.

failures: Additional text beyond the specified title is present: the label 'Input' appears under the first block.
The prompt refinement required removing all text from within or near blocks so that the only text on the slide is the title, which is violated.
The title is not placed clearly in the top-left corner relative to the overall canvas margin (it appears slightly inset but not strongly anchored as described).
attempts.summary: Diagram style and structure (single input compute followed by repeated output compute steps) are correct, but the presence of the extra 'Input' label and minor title placement issues violate the strict text constraints, so the slide does not pass.

All rubric items are met: clean technical diagram with a deadpan feel, exact title text in the top-left, no extra text, and a clear visual story where a single input is processed once and outputs pass through repeated compute blocks sequentially.

All rubric items are satisfied: the slide uses a clean technical vector style, the title is exactly 'Tradeoffs' in the top-left, no extra text is present, and the triangle clearly has corners labeled 'capability', 'cost', and 'latency'.

failures: X-axis label includes an extra arrow symbol not specified in the prompt ('tok/min/GPU →' instead of exactly 'tok/min/GPU').

attempts.summary: Most rubric items are satisfied: clean corporate technical style, correct title text, only the specified textual labels, and a noisy upward-trending scatter plot with correctly labeled axes. However, the x-axis still ends in an arrow glyph, which conflicts with the refinement that the x-axis label text must be exactly 'tok/min/GPU' with no arrow. Removing that arrow would make the slide fully compliant.

All rubric items are satisfied: the style is clean and technical, the title text matches exactly, only the three specified text strings appear, the scatter plot has many points with a noisy upward trend, and the axes are correctly labeled 'tok/min/GPU' and 'ms/token'. The slide passes.

All rubric items are satisfied: clean technical style with subtle shadows and corporate palette, title text exactly 'Congestion' in the top-left, no extra text, a clear queue of multiple incoming request arrows funneled into a single service lane, and a clock icon indicating delay. All rubric items are satisfied: clean technical vector style, title text exactly 'Routing' in the top-left, no extra text, multiple data center nodes with visible network lines, and a clear routing choice implied by two divergent arrows from a central node.

All rubric items are satisfied: clean technical vector style, correct title 'Model size', only specified text present, model sizes clearly labeled, and the latency arrow increases from small to large.

All rubric items are satisfied: clean technical style with subtle shadows, correct title 'Input vs output' in the top-left, only the specified text appears, both input and output segments are clearly labeled, and the output segment visually shows higher cost through larger squares.

All rubric items are satisfied: the style is clean and technical with a dry, deadpan feel; the title text is exactly 'Context + KV' in the top-left; no extra text beyond 'Context + KV' and 'KV' appears; the taller KV stack is visually linked to the longer request strip via the arrow; and the KV block is clearly labeled 'KV'.

All rubric items are satisfied: the style is a clean technical diagram with muted colors and subtle shadows; the title text is exactly 'Cached prefix' in the top-left; the only other text is 'cached' and 'new'; the prompt bar is clearly split and labeled; and output tokens are visually shown after the prompt bar. All rubric items satisfied: clean deadpan technical style, correct title text, only specified labels present, clear batching difficulty on the left, and a rising cost curve on the right.

All rubric items are satisfied: clean technical diagram style with subtle deadpan humor via the sticky note, title text exactly 'Speedups' in the top-left, no extra text beyond the required title, and the visual clearly serves as a section opener for speedups.

All rubric criteria are satisfied: the style is clean and technical with a subtle deadpan feel, the title text is exactly 'Smaller models', only the specified texts 'Smaller models' and 'faster' appear, and the diagram clearly shows smaller model blocks associated with faster speed along the arrow.

failures: No extra text appears beyond the specified labels: The diagram includes unlabeled icons and shapes that are acceptable, but the three small white indicators on the router are arguably textual/semantic marks beyond 'MoE' and 'expert'.

However, the routing does not clearly skip inactive experts, and there is slight ambiguity about extra semantic markings on the router, so it does not fully meet all rubric conditions.

All rubric items are satisfied: clean corporate technical style, title is exactly 'MoE', only additional text is 'expert' on the active blocks, a clear subset of experts are active, and inactive experts are visibly skipped via greyed-out blocks and dashed, non-token-carrying connectors.

All rubric items are satisfied: the slide has a clean corporate technical style with muted tones and subtle shadows; the title in the top-left reads exactly 'Proxy model'; the only other text is 'draft' and 'verify'; a block of five tokens is shown as a swatch; and a verify gate appears after the draft block. The slide passes.

failures: The diagram contains additional text-like glyphs (the small grid of rectangular blocks inside the 16-bit block), which can be interpreted as extra markings beyond the strictly allowed labels 'Quantization', '16-bit', '8-bit', '4-bit'.

All rubric items are satisfied: clean technical style, exact title 'Quantization', only specified text labels, 16/8/4-bit precision levels clearly shown, and a rightward arrow implying speed increase.

All rubric items are met: the slide has a clean corporate technical style, the title text is exactly 'KV cache' in the top-left, only the allowed labels ('KV cache', 'evict') are present, reuse arrows are clearly shown around the KV cache block, and eviction is represented by a dimmed trash bin labeled 'evict' that’s visually de-emphasized relative to the main diagram.

All rubric requirements are met: clean, technical, deadpan style with muted palette and subtle shadows; title text is exactly ‘Do the work’ placed top-left; stamp face reads exactly ‘DO YOUR OWN WORK’; no extra text appears; a large stamp and a slide-like icon are clearly visible; and the composition is intentionally over-the-top with a dramatic burst effect. Minor possible refinement would be making the slide icon read more clearly as a slide graphic rather than a playground slide, but this doesn’t violate any stated criteria.
